reviewText: Decision Before Dawn, 1951 filmThis film is dedicated to the Armed Forces of the USA and the French Army. This story is true, the names have been changed. The story begins with the shooting of a spy. "People are alive as long as they are remembered." One officer is reassigned to G2 because of a war wound. Two Germans surrender to an American officer. Then he reports to his new posting. Can they use German prisoners to gather information? Lt. Rennick will learn by experience when they interrogate prisoners. "How much do you pay?" One German prisoner voices his opinion in front of others. He screams in the night! His buddy volunteers to work for the Americans; he wants people to be free. Can he be trusted? Two will be smuggled across the front lines to gather information. "Good Luck!"Happy is told the rules and learns his new identity. He gets his training. "Tiger" returns and is questioned. Did he tell the truth? A German general wants to surrender if he can make contact with the Americans. They must send in a team to establish clandestine communications. One must be an American, a volunteer (in civilian dress). They are dropped by parachute. "Happy" returns. Damage slows train traffic. A passenger offers to sell him jewelry. We see signs of bomb damage. Does somebody recognize "Happy"? He finds a place to spend the night. The radio tells of a search for a lone paratrooper with Luftwaffe boots. Does he make a mistake about Alsace? A  woman tells of her unhappy past. People are transported in a truck. Who is watching him? The truck is stopped, the men taken away for reinforcements. One deserter is condemned. "Happy" will serve the General as a medic (angina pectoris). He overhears important military information.The General tells they must keep discipline. "Medics save lives, however unworthy, while soldiers take lives however worthy." En route they are attacked by airplanes. "Happy" disposes of a threat, then loses his papers. He avoids a checkpoint! He has no papers now. We see destroyed buildings. An air raid siren ends the search. Can he find a safe house? That German General was wounded, he can't negotiate a deal. The lower ranks can't act. Lt. Rennick must get back to carry the news (the transmitter was damaged). "Tiger" won't return. A young boy overhears their talk and reports them. The hunt is on! The find no one. Can they cross the cold icy river to return to American lines? Soldiers fire at them but they escape. "Happy" surrenders to allow Lt. Rennick to get away to the American lines and report the troop movements. The Colonel speaks about the use of spies. "Too bad about the kid."After William Casey died this movie was shown on a local TV station. Casey served with the OSS during the war. There are books and some movies about the OSS. Some claimed this movie was too sympathetic to the former enemy, even though it dealt with individuals. If everyone in Germany agreed with the Nazis there would have been no need for the Gestapo and camps for political prisoners. The denazification programs purged Germany of the guilty, and there were War Crimes Trials. Was "Happy" a traitor or a hero for working with the Americans? Yes. This is a warning about a country where they have no Bill of Rights (or they are ignored). Was this trip necessary? Yes, even tho the communications of the enemy were being read ("The Ultra Secret"). A failure to send scouts would have warned the enemy about their secret communications.

reviewText: This is a very interesting movie, worth watching. An American WWII movie where  the Germans are positively described and moreover, the hero is a young German POW. Since I'm Mexican, I was very surprised at this fact, because all American war movies I had watched till now had this arrogant portray of the Americans as world saviors. Not this one. It's also outstanding for its locations; shut on the postwar ruined Europe, it has an incredible sense of realism and war weariness. Especially noteworthy is the last 10 minutes sequence when the undercover German "traitors" and the American officer escape ... will they make it? Will the Germans reveal all the plan to their countrymen? Oscar Werner is extraordinary as well as the actor playing the other German spy (sorry, I didn't catch the actor's name).  The script is not so good with the American soldiers portrayal; even my beloved Richard Basehart is quite wooden and declaiming his final lines as a recruiting TV ad for the Marines. Highly recommended for WWII movie fans!
summary: The German is the real hero!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just saw this movie today on TV (not for the first time) and had to review it despite its age.  It has never gotten the attention it deserves I guess because it is too true to life (no sexy blonds or dinner jackets).  It is an excellent example of tactical Human Intelligence (HUMINT) as it was actually conducted by the Office of Stategic Services (OSS) tactical detachments during WWII.  The assessing, recruitment, training and dispatch of the assets all rings true.  One incident that shows the veracity of the movie is when the OSS lieutenant returns to friendly lines and meets up with his fellow OSS members. Some of them see the loss of his best asset on the mission as no big thing because "he was just a traitor" or "just another kraut".  This is truly indicative of the outlook of many people on the fringes of HUMINT with no feel for the art of agent handling. read some of the official histories of the OSS and then watch the movie and you'll see how well the subject matter was handled.
summary: Might Be best Movie About Intelligence Ever
Title: N/A

reviewText: Anatole Litvak's engaging WWII drama "Decision Before Dawn" examines the war from an entirely different perspective.  Filmed in the war ravaged remains of Nazi Germany in 1950, the story commences as American troops are poised to cross the Rhine and enter Germany.  In the waning days of the war an American intelligence detail lead by Col. Devlin played by Gary Merrill and Lt. Rennick played by Richard Basehart are using captured POW's to act as spys.  Using specially trained and suitable German soldiers they hope to gain sensitive information to aid in the war effort.  Oskar Werner playing Cpl. Karl Maurer is just such a man.Werner, an educated son of a physician, and not a loyal Nazi supporter, is a medic in the German Luftwaffe.  He and Basehart along with another Nazi traitor code named Tiger and played by Hans Christian Blech are dropped behind enemy lines to determine the location of crack Panzer units.What makes the film so unique, was that Werner's odyssey through the dying Third Reich gives us insight into the disposition of the German populace.  Their downtrodden existence scrounging out an existence in the final months of the war is a disturbing sight to behold.Litvack's film is a tribute to the nameless German spys who aided the Allied war effort.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was delighted (and rather surprised) to see this long overlooked film getting a much deserved DVD release. It had been many years since I last saw it - on television - but much of it remained vividly in my memory. Finally seeing it again, it's not hard to understand why.Based on a true story and filmed in atmospheric black and white, Decision Before Dawn was made entirely on location among the ruins of postwar Europe - unusual for Hollywood films of the time. The story of German POW's being recruited to work as undercover agents in their own country in late 1944 benefits from understated performances and an almost total lack of background music. Much more of an espionage film than a war movie, the heightened sense of reality serves the stifled emotions and confused motives of the characters perfectly. The film only briefly loses its way once - to include the obligatory fallen female - but even this episode is handled well.Although not top billed, Oskar Werner plays the central character - an idealistic medic caught up in circumstances that have little to do with truth or honesty. One of the finest screen actors ever, Werner gives a superb multi-layered performance, acting as much with his eyes as his voice. The rest of the cast is also good - many of them in far from sympathetic parts. The fact that this was considered a prestige film is underlined by the presence of Richard Basehart, an actor who reputation has underservedly faded over the years.The direction by Anatole Litvak provides just the right mixture of drama and suspense - more genuine suspense than most Hitchcock films. The script is a taut, no-frills affair. It asks questions but provides no easy answers. The film was nominated for a best picture Oscar. Of course, it didn't win and became rather neglected over the years. Not because it's not a good film, which it certainly is, but possibly because it's not just another bit of mindless entertainment. The drama and suspense engage your emotions, but Decision Before Dawn also gives you a lot to think about.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As someone who appreciates great cinematography and on-location shooting I found this film immediately arresting when TCM broadcast it and resolved to add it to my library. I loved Rosellini's "Open City" & "Germany Year Zero," and Staudte's "Murderers Are Among Us," which also deal with WWII and were filmed in is immediate aftermath. There are only a few films that offer us on-location footage from Post-wartime Europe--in this case the area around Wuerzburg. I took DVD Savant's Glenn Erickson by his word when he said the video was of excellent quality. Unfortunately, this is not the first time he has mislead his readers. "Woman in the Window" is another soft transfer he rated as excellent.The bottom line is: if you are acquiring DVDs to watch them on your DVD player or Analog TV this transfer is beyond reproach. But if you like to watch on a HD laptop, as I do, it's tolerable at best. That's just not good enough these days. I'd come to expect better from Fox. Surely this film deserves a real restoration + commentary. Oskar Werner and Hilegard Knef are riveting as two young people in over their heads in a world turned upside down by war. That's reason enough see (if not own) this film.
summary: A great war movie - Just okay DVD

reviewText: "Decision Before Dawn" is a Hollywood propaganda film that demands that American audiences embrace Nazi Germany. Otherwise, it is good to look at -- stark, crisp black-and-white noirish images of bombed out Germany combined with a young Oskar Werner's great physical beauty and sensuality.The film's artistry never overcomes its primary function as propaganda, though, a function revealed in every aspect of the film, from its structure to its on-screen titles to its voice-over narration (provided by Basehart, who did have a remarkable voice) to its cast and its scenes.Unless I missed it, the film never mentions the word "Jew." It does harp endlessly on images of Germans as victims and Germans as nice folks just like you and me who were victimized by a "regime." The film announces overtly and repeatedly that judging Germans would be wrong.The US did this in the post-war era in order to justify the Marshall Plan and the West's rapid embrace of Germany. Horror for Holocaust crimes was deflected to the East, specifically, Poland, as my own book shows.
summary: Propaganda Demanding that Americans Embrace Nazi Germany
Title: N/A

reviewText: Offbeat and emotionally involving tale of German turncoats spying for the Yanks in the closing days of WWII.Largely forgotten, this intelligent thriller captured a best picture Oscar nomination in 1951. Unusual for war films of that period, it pulls no punches about the fears and miseries of that time in Europe. Oskar Werner is sensational as the German traitor motivated to help end the suffering caused by his country's continued resistance to the inevitable Allied victory. Similar in tone to "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold."No extras on this Fox "Heroes of War" series title other than an odd news clip about the film getting an award.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched this with my best friend who generally does not like war films - however he was very involved in the story. The focus is not on "violence" or "victory" - what in "Saving Private Ryan" might be called war realism - but on the whole range of personalities drawn into the conflict - some victims, some monsters, some opportunists, some propagandists, some heroes, many ordinary men and women, and quite a few a mix of all this.The central character is played by "Oscar Werner", an introspective actor rather than a method one.  He is a German soldier wearing a medical Red Cross on the arm of his uniform.  In the beginning of the film he is captured by two Americans.  When the higher ranking American officer offers the captured soldiers drinks of water, his first words are a sincere "thank you."  Oscar Werner gives the impression of being a lonely misunderstood man, an intellectual, and a pacifist.  He kills no one - not even in self defense. Despite the movie being set in cities under bombing attack and other war zones - there is not one scene of a direct killing.  In a war film, the director accomplishes something quite extraordinary -  he makes a movie which reflects an abhorrence of violence.  Nevertheless, the effects of violence are displayed often enough such as a bombed out theater, fires raging in windows of German buildings, a military hanging, and a corpse of a man pushed out of a window.The American plan is to recruit some German POW's to spy for the Allied Powers behind German lines and discover the accurate location of a Panzer Division.  Put in another way, the Americans want German "traitors" to the Nazi cause. One canny soldier accepts the mission solely for opportunistic reasons.  Oscar Werner's medic (a man who disdains violence) accepts the assignment because he feels in his heart the German war machine must be stopped for humanitarian reasons...and he thinks he is serving his country best by ending the slaughter of innocents, some which will be more German soldiers and civilians.At this juncture of the war, after the Allied invasion of Normandy and the Axis disaster at Stalingrad, most Germans know that...in the end...their side will be defeated. Perhaps they calculate six months, a year, or two?  But as German soldiers and officers they follow orders and fight on.The medic travels by parachute, foot, train, and bus looking for the answer to the military question of the location of the Panzer unit. In the process, he encounters many German personalities.  He discovers that his father - a well respected doctor -  is nearby; this good news is stained by the knowledge that the hospital his father has been relocated to will probably be bombed in the upcoming American attack.  He meets an obnoxious SS man who is proud that the Nazi's invasion of the last 12 years will be forever remembered.  He meets a weary but still pretty German woman (played by Hildegarde Kneff) who becomes a prostitute after losing her daughter to Allied bombing.  He meets an ordinary German soldier who loses his glasses. He meets a young boy who is completely indoctrinated by Nazi propaganda. He meets a German General who chooses to execute a deserter, perhaps a decent soldier, solely to scare the Nazi troops to keep on fighting a losing war.  And he meets a neighbor who knows his family.  Oscar Werner's character has to take this all in - and continue to decide to betray the German war effort.  This makes his dilemma all the more real as only a few of the Nazi's are actual villains.Until the very end, it is unclear whether the vital information that the medic discovers can be communicated successfully to the Allies. One problem - it takes little time for the medic's spy name to be on a new list of Germans to be captured..so he must run and hide for his life.Other reviewers have commented that the on-site locations in Europe give the film a dark, realistic feel of Germany in the last days of the war.  It took the director one year and a half to shoot the film the way he wanted it to look - the bombings, the shattered buildings, the fires.The irony of the film is that a turncoat to his country (Oscar Werner) become a quiet hero in the eyes of the American lieutenant assigned to the spy mission. But to all the other American soldiers, the spy is just a mere Kraut, an expendable German, or even a traitor...quickly to be forgotten.
summary: For those who don't like war films - let them sample this

reviewText: This movie looks at a U.S. Army intelligence operation in action during the part of WWII. This operation relied upon former German soldiers recruited from POW camps for missions behind enemy lines. These soldiers were issued new identity documents, orders and other items needed to appear as if they were on leave or in transit to new units. These soldiers would then collect tactical intelligence from within Germany itself (the Front had moved eastward as Germany's fortune faded) and report via radio.Of course, this was a very dangerous job as the Nazi security services were always on the lookout for suspicious-looking documents, German Army units were press-ganging soldiers on leave and in transit in order to bring their own units up to strength and finally there was always the possibility of getting killed by an inadvertant American bomb or artillery shell before returning back to Allied lines.A good drama, filmed in black and white and realistic (when the movie was made German had yet to rebuild from the war) it really sucks you into the story.
summary: Germany in the last days of WWII
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd never seen or heard of "Decision before Dawn" until it appeared in my recommended list on Amazon.com.  Released in 1951, it apparently has been on TV a number of times, but I never caught it.  Having it on DVD, especially at a bargain price, is welcome, indeed.There are no big stars in the movie, although Gary Merrill, Richard Basehart, and Oskar Werner are certainly well-known names.  The story is rather obscure in that it features Germans who change sides at the end of World War II, and end up spying on and fighting the Nazis.  Some of these spies are heroic, like Oskar Werner's character; others are simply mercenary.  In any event, we see that there were some good Germans who were loyal to their country, if not to the savage regime that took it over for 12 years.The movie is in black-and-white, which lends itself well to the feel of the subject.  It comes across almost as a docu-drama, to use modern terminology.  Many of the outdoor shots feel like how Germany must have been in the latter years of the war after allied bombing had reduced most cities to rubble.  You get a sense for the desperation and futility of ordinary people, as well, as the only "love interest" in the show, Hildegard Neff, vanishes almost as quickly as she appears.  And she never is seen again.If you're looking for a film that shows one of the pivotal points of the war, like "The Battle of the Bulge," or "The Battle of Britain," you might be disappointed in this show.  But if you want to see a realistic depiction of patriotic Germans who resisted the Nazis and helped end the war, you should be pleasantly surprised.  Acting is first-rate and the story is well-written and engaging.There is not really a happy ending in "Decision before Dawn," unless you feel that the war is closer to its end as a result of what you've seen.  In that sense, the movie really seems much ahead of its time and should find a receptive audience.  As other reviewers point out, "Decision before Dawn" is really an anti-war film, showing as it does the futility of one group of humans intent on destroying another group.In summing up, I can't think of another movie to compare this one to.  I'd have to say the film is unique and worthy of its place in any World War II collection.
summary: Engaging realism; ahead of its time

reviewText: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation presents "DECISION BEFORE DAWN" (1951) (119 min/B&W;) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) -- With the Third Reich disintegrating, several members of the German army are defecting to the Americans and offering their services as spies --- US officer Gary Merrill trusts none of these last-minute "converts", but German prisoner Oskar Werner seems to be sincere --- Werner insists that by helping the Americans, he is saving Germany from destruction --- Merrill sends Werner behind enemy lines for counter-espionage with an American officer (Richard Basehart), who still isn't convinced that the German expatriate means what he says.A thoughtful World War II drama, Decision Before Dawn was filmed on location in Europe and was Oscar Nominated for Best Picture & Film Editing (Dorothy Spencer).Under the production staff of:Anatole Litvak [Director]Peter Viertel  [Screenplay]George Howe  [novel "Call It Treason"]Carl Zuckmayer  [Dialogue]Anatole Litvak [Producer]Frank McCarthy [Producer]Franz Waxman  [Original Film Music]Franz Planer [Cinematographer]Dorothy Spencer [Film Editor]Ludwig Reiber [Art Director]BIOS:1. reviewText: This a reasonably compelling and thoughtful film on spies in wartime. Its about the recruitment and use of prisoners of war as frontline spies. German prisoners in this case. Its strength is in its straightforward presentation, its attention to detail in the backgrounds and an ability to effectively present moral ambiguity and confusion.The period detail in the film is a combination of time it was shot (a few years after the war) and the attention people on the film seem to have put into getting things right. Even minor things like the details of checkpoints and air raids seem more realistic than in almost any film I can remember. The violence is also meaningful from a miilitary hanging to prisoners of war killing a man they saw as a traitor.The main character is a very confused young man whose motives, while good, are open to any number of interpretations. To me, he seems most motivated by a need to please those around him. His confused motives and internal conflict make him a compelling character. The film takes things too far on occasion. Having him decide to collaborate to a degree that he puts his own father's life at risk is a bit too much. On the good side, nearly all of the German characters are fleshed out as real people rather than being morality sockpuppets.The film shys away from stating the obvious. That these sort of "amature" spy operations conducted out of an army headquarters late in the war were a total waste of time and lives. The POW is sent running all over Germany to pin down the location of one unit. There is window-dressing about a german corps surrendering, but its rather pointless. The attitude of the American intelligence officers is captured well with a few bad exceptions. They capture well, especially at the end, how disposable these people that they are using are. The film makes its points about spying better and more effectively than John le Carré has across many books.It was also good in illustrating how dangerous and foolish this sort of spying was. The spy is as good as caught on arrival. The need for papers, the careful control of transportation and all the checkpoints around the front lines make it likely to fail from the start. One other thing they did better than most is show the presence of women in various roles in the war.All in all, a mostly good film. Very interesting to watch in terms of period detail and a morally complicated story.

reviewText: PLOT: German soldiers recruited by Americans to gain info behind the German Lines~1945~ The last PUSH into Nazi Germany~ and the Americans are "recruiting" volunteer German Soldiers to drop behind the German Lines for "military information"~ Richard Basehart is first rate as a "radio operator" chose to head the team to parachute into Germany with a real German solider~ "Happy" (code name) for Oskar Werner. Happy is a young german medic who volunteers to what he sees as helping end the war. This is exciting as end up in Mannheim. Happy is travels alone and ends up saving a general and then is soon stalked by a Gestapo Agent hot on his trail. This is excellent as we see the bombed out buildings and the "real" crumbling of Germany at the end of the War. As the team "gather" for the final "push" to return over the Rhine River~ to get BACK to the American sides~ Hildeguarde Neff as a "German PICK UP girl" who attempts to help spy on Happy and ends up having him help her~ Oskar Werner is excellent as the very young and "good" soldier who cares about Germany but just wants the war to "end". The dark dirty and depressing look inside Germany is worth the watch let alone the PLOT and Warner give us a first rate performance. Basehart is good and I give this one 5 STARS for good WW2 movie.
summary: German's helping American Soldiers~ behind the lines~ 5 STARS~ VG~

reviewText: The acting, dialog, and plot of this movie are stilted and crude. The characters are more like types from an Army training manual than real people. The moral lessons are at pre-K level. But this movie is filmed in Europe in the years immediately following WWII, with real uniforms, real settings, real war equipment, and historically accurate events. Taken by itself, this is a 2 star movie at best. With its superlative realism, the movie is a 4 star movie, a must-see for any student of history and any fan of war movies.

reviewText: Richard Basehart plays a US Army Intelligence Officer who recruits former German Army POW's (Oskar Werner)to go back into Germany to gather information to help the Allies near the end of the war. Tough, realistic view of spys and the intelligence business. A very good film and well worth watching. One of the best of this genre.

reviewText: Overall, this is a 4.5 star movie, because of its drama and how it deals with the duplicity of the spy business. However, it has some rough spots. If you are one of those people who doesn't have the patience to stick with a movie for about 10 minutes to see if it evolves into solid entertainment, then you'll be put off.The first five minutes, and maybe the last five minutes of this film are stilted. Baseheart and his Army sgt. driver get lost and find a couple of escaping German Luftwaffe anti-air artillery soldiers in the French woodland. The way they go about taking them prisoner is just laughable. Sounds like a 1930s gangster flick.Also, the sgt. driver turns over a Lugar he's taken off the German officer.This is a special outfit that needs German clothing, razor blades and such, but I don't think the sgt. would just cough up the Lugar. You get a pistol, then you keep it to trade for other more important stuff.After that, this film settles down to a pretty good "fish out of water" spy flick. Oskar Werner turns in a good performance as the German soldier who volunteers to go back into his own country and spy for the Allies.Then there's the last two minutes of the film. Wow, it sounds like some kind of training film narration tacked on, and it probably was. It really sounds more like a "Hey Reds we are coming for you too" kind of thing. That's fine when you are scared of commies too, I guess, but it kind of sounds silly in the 21st Century.I won't give away too much, but this film is worth the 95 minutes or so you take to watch it.
